comments:
When adding a public key secured cvs repository I got the very helpful error 
message: Error validating location: "" 
I added the repository though, but of course wasn't able to connect. When 
attempting to open the HEAD I got an error: "Fetching children of HEAD" with an 
NPE. 
After several hours of searching for an solution without being able to make any 
progress in my work I finally found out that I have to reduce the size of my 
RSA key from 4096 to 1024 bits (don't know if 2048 etc works). Now I'm able to 
connect without any problems...

Yamanaka, is there a key length restriction in the jsch client?

Isn't blocking since there is a workaround. Changing severity.

Thanks Alex, you just saved me from getting mad. This nasty little bug has kept 
me busy for the last 3 hours :) 
With a smaller key it works like a charm! 
 
I fully agree on the usefullness of the error messages... 
 
BTW: Is it possible to use a native ssh client? Why reinvent the wheel (at 
least on unix/linux platform) particularly for security relevant things?

Confirm that this bug also happens for 2048-bit keys. NPE is

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 4 2 Oct 17, 2004 10:42:06.337
!MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Fetching children of HEAD".
!STACK 0
java.lang.NullPointerException
        at com.jcraft.jsch.Buffer.putString(Unknown Source)
        at com.jcraft.jsch.UserAuthPublicKey.start(Unknown Source)
        at com.jcraft.jsch.Session.connect(Unknown Source)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ssh2.JSchSession.getSession(JSchSessio
n.java:314)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ssh2.CVSSSH2ServerConnection.internalO
pen(CVSSSH2ServerConnection.java:117)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ssh2.CVSSSH2ServerConnection.open(CVSS
SH2ServerConnection.java:99)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.core.connection.Connection.open(Connec
tion.java:127)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.core.connection.CVSRepositoryLocation.
createConnection(CVSRepositoryLocation.java:575)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.core.connection.CVSRepositoryLocation.
openConnection(CVSRepositoryLocation.java:821)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.core.client.Session.open(Session.java:
142)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.core.resources.RemoteFolderMemberFetch
er.performUpdate(RemoteFolderMemberFetcher.java:115)
Now, the code in the CVS repository will not throw NPE for such a large key.
Yamanaka, does this mean that keys > 1024 bits are now supported?

|Yamanaka, does this mean that keys > 1024 bits are now supported?

No.  
It depends on the implementation of JCE(Java Cryptgraphy Extension) 
included in the Java runtime.  On my environment, I had that problems 
for 5120 bits key, but I did not get such a problem for 2048 bits.  
Anyway, I think that almost of all users, who understand what they are 
doing, will not choose such a large key.
So, IMHO, it is not required to support them.
The current implmentation will just fail for that key, 
but will not be crashed.

Based on Yamanaka's last comment, it appears that we support reasonably sized 
keys and fail gracefully when a key that is too large is used. It also sounds 
like there is no pla to support larger keys in JSch on which the SSH2 plugin 
in Eclipse depends so I'm marking this as wontfix.
